Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dimensions US-Biota Sao Paulo: Chemically mediated multi-trophic interaction diversity across tropical gradients
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will examine the diversity and ecological complexity of plants and associated insects in forests across a variable landscape in Brazil. Plants, insects, and their predators make up over half of all known organisms, and their interactions are essential to ecosystem health. This is especially true for tropical forests, where ecologists are only beginning to understand the nature and complexity of these interactions. In particular, little is known about: 1) the diversity of plant chemicals that deter insect herbivory and affect other plants and animals, 2) how diversity of these plant chemicals varies within and between plant species, and 3) how plant chemistry can affect the diversity and productivity of entire forests. Recent advances in chemistry and molecular biology provide the opportunity to understand the diversity of plant-insect interactions at three different levels (chemical, genetic, and taxonomic) with unprecedented scope and depth. These new methods will be integrated and enhanced by a unique team of U.S. and Brazilian scientists to investigate the diversity of insect-plant food webs, how they are shaped by plant chemical defenses and environmental gradients, and how this diversity affects forest stability and productivity. The research will contribute to understanding how large global changes in biodiversity and climate will affect plant-insect-predator interactions, how plant genetic and chemical diversity influences plant-feeding, and how taxonomic and genetic diversity of insect predators can affect control of harmful insects. The comprehensive sampling and methods used in this project will result in the discovery of new species of plants and insects, new biologically active molecules, and are likely to deliver new tools and approaches that have powerful applications in agriculture and medicine. This international and multi-disciplinary research project will have broad impacts by involving K-12 students, science teachers, and citizen scientists. Discoveries will be widely communicated to the public via websites, and scientific and popular publications.

This project is focused on a highly diverse system involving plants in the genus Piper (Piperaceae), associated herbivores, and parasitic wasps and flies. The research will utilize cutting edge approaches to studying biodiversity that link measures of interaction diversity to genetic diversity, population genetic structure, and plant chemical diversity involving the following components: 1) Large scale sampling of herbivores and their parasitoids on diverse Piper species across an array of sites to assess effects of abiotic gradients on community structure and ecosystem processes, and to acquire specimens for taxonomic, genomic, and phytochemical analysis. 2) Field experiments where taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity will be manipulated along with abiotic factors to strengthen inferences from statistical analysis of field surveys, community genetics, and measures of metabolite diversity. 3) Taxonomic and systematic analysis of plants, herbivores, and parasitoids using traditional and novel methods (genomics) to document and describe new taxa, understand their relationships, and reveal cryptic diversity. 4) Population genomic analyses of plants, herbivores, and parasitoids to understand how geography, plant phylogeny and chemistry influence population structure and genetic differentiation across trophic levels. 5) Characterization of metabolite diversity of Piper species; how metabolite diversity varies with phylogeny, ecology, and herbivore pressure; and the effect of phytochemical diversity on higher trophic levels. The combination of quantitative sampling along elevational gradients, newly developed metabolomics methods, population genomics, and a large scale experiment will make possible tests of emerging hypotheses about relationships between plant chemistry, and different dimensions of diversity, and will represent the first large scale, among-site plant-herbivore-parasitoid food-web comparison in the tropics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The broad aim of our collaborative NSF Dimensions of Biodiversity project was to understand the diversity and complex interactions between plants, their insect herbivores (caterpillars), and the enemies of those herbivores (parasitic wasps and flies), and how they vary across environments. This is important not only for our basic understanding of biodiversity and ecology, but also because these organisms and their interactions are fundamental to the agro-ecosystems we rely on and what we learn from them can inform sustainability and conservation. The focus of my laboratory’s portion of the award was the taxonomic, genetic, and interaction diversity of parasitoid flies in the family Tachinidae (bristle flies), and their interactions with their host insects. Parasitoids are insects that develop on and kill their host organism. Parasitoid flies are key enemies of herbivorous insects across the globe, including many crop and forest pests. Despite their ecological importance, they have been little studied and we know nothing about most species. Understanding their taxonomy and diversity (what species are out there and how are they related), and their biology (what they do and how they do it), is necessary to more effectively conserve them and their valuable ecological roles in managed and unmanaged ecosystems. Our specific goals included: 1) documenting parasitoid-host-host plant interactions, 2) taxonomic description and systematic characterization of tachinid parasitoids, and 3) assessment of diversity and evolutionary relationships of these parasitoids and how it is influenced by species interactions and geography.

Major outcomes

Support from this subaward has resulted in the publication of nearly 20 manuscripts dealing with the evolution, and ecology of parasitoid flies and related topics, with at least five more in preparation and dozens more from the larger collaborative project. Together these studies represent substantial contributions towards our knowledge of parasitoid insect diversity, evolution and taxonomy and their interactions with host caterpillars in a tritrophic context. Some of the major achievements documented in these manuscripts include:

-          Documenting a global latitudinal gradient in insect herbivore specialization.

-          Creation of a worldwide evolutionary reconstruction of the diverse and important bristle flies (Tachinidae; Fig. 1), and focused analyses of relationships of the bug-killing flies (Phasiinae).

-          Revealing patterns of diversification and adaptive radiation of the bristle flies and its underlying causes (Fig. 2).

-          Reconstructions of relationships and history of the higher flies (Oestroidea), including the first fossil description (Fig. 3), dating of divergence times, and erection of a new fly family, the Polleniidae.

-          Taxonomic revisions and descriptions of bristle fly groups including Winthemiini, Glaurocarini, Pelamerini, and Eucelatoria.

-          Characterization and analysis of bristle fly-caterpillar interactions in the Ecuadorian Andes (Fig. 4) and in North America involving Monarch butterflies.

-          The first full inventory and analysis of fly biodiversity at a tropical site.

-          Documentation and analysis of geographic patterns of tachinid diversity and its underlying causes (Figure 5).

We are nearing completion of several additional projects that were supported by this funding that will result in major contributions to our scientific understanding of bristle flies and their interactions with hosts. These include:

-          Taxonomic revision and analysis of the Neotropical bristle fly tribe Polideini (Fig. 6).

-          Taxonomic revision of the American bristle fly genus Xanthophyto (important parasitoids of conifer pests).

-          Environmental impacts on tachinid-caterpillar interaction webs in Costa Rica.

-          An understanding of the impact of invasive plants on native insect communities in North America.

Intellectual Merit

Together these products of our research represent a major step forward in understanding the diversity, biology, and ecology of the bristle flies and their caterpillar hosts. They represent some of the first documentations of biodiversity patterns of bristle flies (and flies generally), the first thorough analyses of their evolution and relationships, and the first analyses of their species-interactions in the Neotropics. Our results have implications far beyond our particular focal study organisms. They have informed our basic understanding of the geographic distribution of biodiversity and patterns of niche specialization, the underlying causes of animal diversity and diversification, and the history of life on Earth.

Broader Impacts

In addition to scientific products including databases, museum specimens, publications, and conference presentations, this award has served to support the education and training of numerous graduate and undergraduate students at Wright State University. This includes two PhD students, two Master’s students, two undergraduate research technicians, and ten undergraduate students that worked in the laboratory for research credit or as volunteers. A majority of these students were female and several were of minorities, which are underrepresented in STEM fields. In addition, the lab has hosted two high school students as summer interns, who received training in biodiversity, entomology, and ecology. We have also broadly engaged with the public to promote science education, especially about insects, through school discovery programs, job shadowing opportunities, and public nature tours.
